decision.title: New Competition Protection Law Strengthens Agency Powers and Aligns with EU Standards
decision.summary: The Ministry of Economic Development published a draft law amending Montenegro's Competition Protection Act on February 18. The amendments give the Competition Protection Agency expanded investigative and enforcement powers, with fines for violations reaching up to 10% of global revenue. The law harmonizes Montenegro's competition framework with EU standards, strengthening the Agency's operational and financial independence. Reported by Portal Analitika.
decision.title_mne: Novi zakon o zaštiti konkurencije jača ovlašćenja Agencije i usklađuje se sa standardima EU
decision.summary_mne: Ministarstvo ekonomskog razvoja objavilo je 18. februara nacrt zakona kojim se mijenja Zakon o zaštiti konkurencije Crne Gore. Izmjenama se Agenciji za zaštitu konkurencije daju proširena istražna i izvršna ovlašćenja, a kazne za prekršaje mogu dostići do 10% globalnog prihoda. Zakon usklađuje crnogorski okvir zaštite konkurencije sa standardima EU, jačajući operativnu i finansijsku nezavisnost Agencije. Prenosi Portal Analitika.

assessments.summary: The new Competition Protection Law is primarily an economic regulatory measure with no direct impact on the education sector. However, its contribution to EU accession alignment has indirect positive implications for education, as Montenegro's progress on economic governance chapters strengthens the overall reform credibility needed to advance education-related chapters and unlock EU funding instruments like Erasmus+ and IPA III education components.
assessments.executive_summary: This competition law reform has no direct bearing on education policy but carries modest indirect benefits through EU accession momentum. The Ministry of Education sees no concerns but recommends leveraging the same harmonization energy to advance overdue reforms in education-specific EU alignment areas such as the European Qualifications Framework and mutual recognition of diplomas.
assessments.reasoning: The draft amendments to the Competition Protection Act are squarely within the domain of economic regulation and Chapter 8 (Competition Policy) of the EU acquis. The education sector is not a direct stakeholder in competition enforcement. That said, several indirect linkages deserve consideration. First, a stronger competition framework can improve market conditions in the education-adjacent private sector, including private universities, textbook publishing, edtech providers, and school supply procurement. Fairer competition could reduce costs for educational institutions and ensure better value in public procurement for school infrastructure and materials. Second, Montenegro's EU accession process is holistic. Demonstrable progress on economic governance chapters signals institutional maturity that supports the country's negotiating position across all chapters, including Chapter 26 (Education and Culture). Every step toward EU regulatory alignment improves Montenegro's standing for accessing pre-accession education funds under IPA III and for deeper integration into Erasmus+ and Horizon Europe. Third, the law's emphasis on institutional independence and operational capacity mirrors the kind of governance reform the education sector itself needs. The Bureau for Education Services, the Agency for Quality Assurance in Higher Education, and the Qualifications Framework Authority all require similar strengthening of independence, capacity, and enforcement powers. The competition law reform could serve as a governance model. However, the direct impact on classroom quality, teacher training, student welfare, VET reform, or brain drain is negligible. The Ministry of Education cannot assign a positive or negative verdict to a decision that fundamentally operates outside its domain.
key_concerns: No direct impact on education quality, student welfare, or teacher workforce development

Risk that political attention and reform energy concentrate on economic chapters while education-specific EU alignment (EQF implementation, Bologna Process compliance, ENIC-NARIC reforms) continues to lag
Private higher education institutions could be affected by competition enforcement but no consultation with education stakeholders appears to have occurred

Procurement processes for educational materials and school construction could be affected by stricter competition rules, requiring awareness and adaptation from school administrators and municipal education authorities
recommendations: Use the momentum of this EU harmonization effort to accelerate alignment of the National Qualifications Framework with the European Qualifications Framework, which remains incomplete

Request that the Competition Protection Agency include education-sector markets (private universities, textbook publishing, school catering, edtech) in its monitoring priorities to ensure fair competition benefits students and institutions
Advocate for similar governance reforms in education regulatory bodies, particularly strengthening the independence and enforcement capacity of the Agency for Quality Assurance in Higher Education
Ensure that municipal and school-level procurement officers receive guidance on how the new competition rules affect their purchasing processes for educational materials and services

counter_proposal.title: Parallel Education Governance Modernization Initiative
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Education would propose a companion reform package that applies the same principles of institutional independence, enforcement capacity, and EU alignment to education regulatory bodies. Just as the Competition Protection Agency is being empowered, so too should the Agency for Quality Assurance in Higher Education, the Bureau for Education Services, and the Qualifications Framework Authority be given enhanced mandates, operational independence, and adequate resourcing.
key_changes: Draft amendments to the Law on Higher Education to strengthen the independence and enforcement powers of the Agency for Quality Assurance in Higher Education, mirroring the competition agency reform model
Accelerate full implementation of the National Qualifications Framework aligned with the EQF, with a dedicated budget and timeline
Establish a cross-ministerial working group between the Ministry of Economic Development and the Ministry of Education to ensure competition enforcement considers education-sector market dynamics
Include education procurement transparency requirements as part of the broader competition reform package
expected_benefits: Faster progress on Chapter 26 (Education and Culture) negotiations with the EU
Improved quality assurance in higher education through a more independent and capable agency
Better value for money in education procurement through competition-aware purchasing
Coherent governance reform narrative that strengthens Montenegro's overall EU accession case
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The legislative and institutional reform models already exist in the competition law package and can be adapted. The main constraints are political will to prioritize education governance reform and the limited human resource capacity in Montenegro's small public administration. A realistic timeline would be 12 to 18 months for drafting and consultation.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Inicijativa za modernizaciju paralelnog upravljanja obrazovanjem
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo prosvjete predložilo bi prateći reformski paket koji primjenjuje ista načela institucionalne nezavisnosti, kapaciteta za sprovođenje i usklađenosti s EU na tijela regulacije obrazovanja. Baš kao što se osposobljava Agencija za zaštitu konkurencije, tako bi i Agencija za kontrolu i obezbjeđivanje kvaliteta visokog obrazovanja, Zavod za obrazovne usluge i Organ za kvalifikacijski okvir trebalo da dobiju proširene mandate, operativnu nezavisnost i odgovarajuće resurse.
key_changes_mne: Nacrt izmjena Zakona o visokom obrazovanju radi jačanja nezavisnosti i ovlašćenja za sprovođenje Agencije za kontrolu i obezbjeđivanje kvaliteta visokog obrazovanja, po uzoru na model reforme agencije za zaštitu konkurencije
Ubrzati potpunu primjenu Nacionalnog okvira kvalifikacija usklađenog s EQF-om, uz namjenski budžet i vremenski plan

Uspostaviti međuresornu radnu grupu između Ministarstva ekonomskog razvoja i Ministarstva prosvjete kako bi se osiguralo da sprovođenje konkurencije uzima u obzir dinamiku tržišta u sektoru obrazovanja
Uključiti zahtjeve za transparentnost u nabavkama u obrazovanju kao dio šireg reformskog paketa u oblasti konkurencije
expected_benefits_mne: Brži napredak u pregovorima s EU u okviru Poglavlja 26 (Obrazovanje i kultura)
Poboljšanje kontrole kvaliteta u visokom obrazovanju putem nezavisnije i sposobnije agencije
Bolja vrijednost novca u obrazovnim nabavkama kroz kupovinu svjesnu konkurencije
Koherentan narativ o reformi upravljanja koji jača ukupan slučaj Crne Gore za pristupanje EU
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno izvodljivo. Modeli zakonodavnih i institucionalnih reformi već postoje u paketu zakona o konkurenciji i mogu se prilagoditi. Glavna ograničenja su politička volja za davanje prioriteta reformi upravljanja obrazovanjem i ograničen kapacitet ljudskih resursa u maloj crnogorskoj javnoj upravi. Realan vremenski okvir za izradu nacrta i konsultacije bio bi od 12 do 18 mjeseci.

assessments.summary_mne: Novi Zakon o zaštiti konkurencije predstavlja prije svega ekonomsku regulatornu mjeru bez neposrednog uticaja na oblast obrazovanja. Međutim, njegov doprinos usklađivanju s EU ima posredne pozitivne implikacije za obrazovanje, budući da napredak Crne Gore u poglavljima ekonomskog upravljanja jača ukupni kredibilitet reformi neophodan za napredak poglavlja vezanih za obrazovanje i otvaranje instrumenata EU finansiranja kao što su Erasmus+ i obrazovne komponente IPA III.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ova reforma zakona o konkurenciji nema neposrednog uticaja na obrazovnu politiku, ali donosi skromne posredne koristi kroz zamah procesa pristupanja EU. Ministarstvo prosvjete ne uočava razloge za zabrinutost, ali preporučuje da se ista energija usklađivanja iskoristi za ubrzavanje zakašnjelih reformi u oblastima usklađivanja obrazovanja s EU, poput Evropskog okvira kvalifikacija i uzajamnog priznavanja diploma.
key_concerns_mne: Nema neposrednog uticaja na kvalitet obrazovanja, dobrobit učenika ili razvoj nastavnog kadra

Postoji rizik da se politička pažnja i reformska energija usredotoče na ekonomska poglavlja, dok specifično usklađivanje obrazovanja s EU (implementacija EQF-a, usklađenost s Bolonjskim procesom, reforme ENIC-NARIC) nastavlja zaostajati
Privatne visokoškolske ustanove mogle bi biti pogođene primjenom propisa o konkurenciji, ali se čini da nije provedeno savjetovanje s akterima iz oblasti obrazovanja

Na postupke javne nabavke obrazovnih materijala i izgradnje škola mogli bi uticati stroži propisi o konkurenciji, što zahtijeva osvješćivanje i prilagođavanje školskih administratora i opštinskih prosvjetnih vlasti
recommendations_mne: Iskoristiti zamah ovog napora na usklađivanju s EU radi ubrzavanja usklađivanja Nacionalnog okvira kvalifikacija s Evropskim okvirom kvalifikacija, koji je još uvijek nedovršen

Zatražiti od Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije da tržišta u sektoru obrazovanja (privatni univerziteti, izdavaštvo udžbenika, školska ishrana, edtek) uvrsti u prioritete praćenja, kako bi se osiguralo da poštena konkurencija koristi studentima i institucijama

Zalagati se za slične reforme upravljanja u regulatornim tijelima za obrazovanje, a posebno za jačanje nezavisnosti i kapaciteta provođenja propisa Agencije za osiguranje kvaliteta u visokom obrazovanju
Osigurati da opštinski i školski službenici za javne nabavke dobiju smjernice o tome kako novi propisi o konkurenciji utiču na njihove postupke nabavke obrazovnih materijala i usluga

assessments.summary: This competition law reform falls outside the direct mandate of the Ministry of Environment. While it does not address environmental protection, coastal management, waste, or climate policy, a stronger competition framework can have indirect positive effects on environmental outcomes by curbing monopolistic practices in waste management, energy, and construction sectors. The decision is relevant to EU accession broadly but does not advance Chapter 27 alignment specifically.
assessments.executive_summary: The Competition Protection Law reform is primarily an economic governance measure with no direct environmental impact. Indirect benefits may arise if stronger competition enforcement addresses market distortions in waste management and energy sectors. The Ministry of Environment recommends ensuring that competition policy tools are leveraged to support environmental objectives where sectors overlap.
assessments.reasoning:
The draft law amending the Competition Protection Act is fundamentally an economic regulation measure aimed at aligning Montenegro with EU competition standards under Chapter 8 (Competition Policy) of the accession negotiations. It does not directly touch upon any of the core environmental domains: environmental protection, coastal zone management, national parks, waste management, climate change, or spatial planning.

However, there are indirect linkages worth noting. Montenegro's waste management sector has long suffered from market concentration and opaque procurement, particularly in municipal waste collection and landfill operations. A stronger Competition Protection Agency with genuine investigative powers could help address anti-competitive behavior among waste operators, potentially lowering costs and improving service quality. Similarly, in the energy sector, competition enforcement could influence the transition away from coal (TPP Pljevlja) by ensuring fair market access for renewable energy producers.

The construction and real estate sectors, which are closely tied to spatial planning and coastal zone management, are also areas where anti-competitive practices (bid-rigging in public tenders, market allocation among developers) have been reported. Stronger enforcement could indirectly support more transparent and environmentally sound spatial development.

That said, the law as described does not incorporate any environmental considerations into competition analysis, such as sustainability agreements or green exemptions, which the EU itself has been developing under its revised Horizontal Guidelines (2023). This represents a missed opportunity to align competition policy with environmental goals.

From a Chapter 27 perspective, this law does not contribute to closing any of the environmental benchmarks. Montenegro's primary environmental challenges remain waste infrastructure gaps, air quality compliance at Pljevlja, water and wastewater treatment deficits, and Natura 2000 network preparation. These require dedicated sectoral legislation and investment, not competition law reform.
key_concerns: The law does not incorporate any environmental sustainability considerations into competition assessments, missing an opportunity to align with evolving EU practice on green agreements.
No mechanism is established for coordination between the Competition Protection Agency and environmental regulators such as the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or the Ministry of Ecology.
The reform does not address competition distortions specific to environmentally sensitive sectors like waste management, energy, or coastal construction.
Focus on economic governance reforms may divert political attention and institutional capacity from urgently needed Chapter 27 environmental legislation.
recommendations: Encourage the Ministry of Economic Development to include sustainability exemptions or guidelines in the competition framework, consistent with the European Commission's 2023 Horizontal Guidelines on sustainability agreements.

Establish a formal consultation mechanism between the Competition Protection Agency and the Environmental Protection Agency for cases involving environmentally sensitive sectors such as waste, energy, and construction.

Use the strengthened competition enforcement tools to investigate anti-competitive practices in Montenegro's waste collection and disposal market, which has been characterized by limited competition and poor service quality.

Ensure that this economic governance reform does not crowd out legislative and institutional attention from pending Chapter 27 obligations, including the transposition of the Industrial Emissions Directive and the Waste Framework Directive.

counter_proposal.title: Green Competition Integration Protocol
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Environment would propose amending the draft competition law to include provisions for sustainability agreements and mandatory inter-agency consultation on cases involving sectors with significant environmental impact. This would align Montenegro not only with current EU competition standards but also with the EU's forward-looking integration of environmental objectives into competition policy.
key_changes: Add a provision allowing sustainability agreements between competitors to be exempt from anti-competitive restrictions when they generate net environmental benefits, following the EU Horizontal Guidelines model.
Mandate that the Competition Protection Agency consult the Environmental Protection Agency before issuing decisions in sectors covered by Chapter 27 (waste, water, energy, construction).
Include environmental market definition criteria so that competition assessments in sectors like waste management account for environmental service quality, not just price.
Require the Competition Protection Agency to publish an annual report on enforcement actions in environmentally sensitive sectors.
expected_benefits: Alignment with the EU's evolving approach to integrating environmental sustainability into competition policy.
Improved oversight of anti-competitive practices in waste management and energy sectors that currently undermine environmental outcomes.
Stronger institutional coordination between economic and environmental regulators, reducing policy silos.
Demonstration of cross-cutting EU integration commitment, which could positively influence Chapter 27 assessment reports.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The proposed amendments are modest in scope and would not require significant additional resources. The main challenge would be securing inter-ministerial agreement, as the Ministry of Economic Development may resist expanding the scope of what is conceived as a purely economic law. However, EU precedent strongly supports the integration of sustainability considerations into competition frameworks.
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo životne sredine predložilo bi izmjenu nacrta zakona o zaštiti konkurencije kako bi se uključile odredbe o sporazumima o održivosti i obaveznim međuagencijskim konsultacijama u predmetima koji se odnose na sektore sa značajnim uticajem na životnu sredinu. Time bi Crna Gora bila usklađena ne samo sa trenutnim EU standardima u oblasti konkurencije, već i sa naprednim pristupom EU koji integriše ekološke ciljeve u politiku konkurencije.
key_changes_mne: Dodati odredbu kojom se sporazumi o održivosti između konkurenata izuzimaju od antikonkurentskih ograničenja kada donose neto ekološke koristi, slijedeći model EU Horizontalnih smjernica.

Obavezati Agenciju za zaštitu konkurencije da se konsultuje s Agencijom za zaštitu životne sredine prije donošenja odluka u sektorima obuhvaćenim Poglavljem 27 (otpad, voda, energetika, građevinarstvo).

Uvesti kriterijume za definisanje tržišta zasnovane na zaštiti životne sredine, kako bi se procjene konkurencije u sektorima poput upravljanja otpadom odnosile i na kvalitet ekoloških usluga, a ne samo na cijenu.
Obavezati Agenciju za zaštitu konkurencije da godišnje objavljuje izvještaj o mjerama izvršavanja zakona u ekološki osjetljivim sektorima.
expected_benefits_mne: Usklađenost sa razvijajućim se pristupom EU u pogledu integracije ekološke održivosti u politiku konkurencije.
Poboljšan nadzor antikonkurentskih praksi u sektorima upravljanja otpadom i energetike, koji trenutno narušavaju ekološke ishode.
Jača institucionalna koordinacija između ekonomskih i ekoloških regulatora, uz smanjenje politike usitnjenosti nadležnosti.
Demonstracija međusektorske posvećenosti evropskim integracijama, koja bi mogla pozitivno uticati na izvještaje o ocjeni Poglavlja 27.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno izvodljivo. Predložene izmjene su skromnog obima i ne bi zahtijevale značajne dodatne resurse. Glavni izazov bio bi postizanje međuresornog dogovora, budući da Ministarstvo ekonomskog razvoja može pružiti otpor proširenju okvira zakona koji se u osnovi doživljava kao isključivo ekonomski. Međutim, EU presedani snažno podržavaju integraciju razmatranja održivosti u okvire politike konkurencije.

assessments.summary_mne: Ova reforma zakona o zaštiti konkurencije izlazi van neposrednog mandata Ministarstva životne sredine. Iako se ne bavi zaštitom životne sredine, upravljanjem obalnim područjem, otpadom ni klimatskom politikom, čvršći okvir konkurencije može imati posredne pozitivne efekte na ekološke ishode, suzbijanjem monopolističkih praksi u sektorima upravljanja otpadom, energetike i građevinarstva. Odluka je relevantna za pristupanje EU u širem smislu, ali ne unapređuje konkretno usklađivanje s Poglavljem 27.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Reforma Zakona o zaštiti konkurencije prvenstveno je mjera ekonomskog upravljanja bez neposrednog uticaja na životnu sredinu. Posredne koristi mogu se pojaviti ukoliko snažnije provođenje propisa o konkurenciji otkloni tržišne poremećaje u sektorima upravljanja otpadom i energetike. Ministarstvo životne sredine preporučuje da se instrumenti politike konkurencije iskoriste za podršku ekološkim ciljevima u sektorima u kojima se oblasti preklapaju.
key_concerns_mne: Zakon ne uključuje nikakva razmatranja ekološke održivosti u ocjene konkurencije, čime se propušta prilika da se uskladi s evolucijom prakse EU u pogledu zelenih sporazuma.
Nije uspostavljen nikakav mehanizam za koordinaciju između Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i ekoloških regulatora, kao što su Agencija za zaštitu životne sredine (AZŽS) ili Ministarstvo ekologije.
Reforma ne bavi se narušavanjem konkurencije specifičnim za ekološki osjetljive sektore kao što su upravljanje otpadom, energetika ili priobalna gradnja.
Fokus na reforme ekonomskog upravljanja može odvratiti političku pažnju i institucionalske kapacitete od hitno potrebnog zakonodavstva u oblasti životne sredine u okviru Poglavlja 27.
recommendations_mne: Podsticati Ministarstvo ekonomskog razvoja da u okvir konkurencije uključi izuzetke ili smjernice vezane za održivost, u skladu s Horizontalnim smjernicama Evropske komisije iz 2023. godine o sporazumima u oblasti održivosti.

Uspostaviti formalni mehanizam konsultacija između Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i Agencije za zaštitu životne sredine za slučajeve koji se tiču ekološki osjetljivih sektora kao što su otpad, energetika i građevinarstvo.

Koristiti ojačane instrumente provođenja propisa o konkurenciji za istraživanje antikonkurentskih praksi na crnogorskom tržištu prikupljanja i odlaganja otpada, koje karakterišu ograničena konkurencija i loš kvalitet usluga.

Osigurati da ova reforma ekonomskog upravljanja ne potisne zakonodavnu i institucionalnu pažnju s neispunjenih obaveza iz Poglavlja 27, uključujući transpoziciju Direktive o industrijskim emisijama i Okvirne direktive o otpadu.

assessments.summary: The strengthening of Montenegro's Competition Protection Agency and alignment with EU competition standards is a positive development for the health sector, particularly regarding pharmaceutical market regulation, healthcare service pricing, and prevention of anti-competitive practices that inflate costs for the RFZO and patients. While not a health-sector-specific law, its indirect effects on drug pricing, medical device procurement, and private healthcare market oversight are significant and welcome.
assessments.executive_summary: This competition law reform is broadly positive for health outcomes in Montenegro, primarily through its potential to curb anti-competitive behavior in pharmaceutical distribution and healthcare procurement. The Ministry of Health's main concern is ensuring the Competition Protection Agency develops sector-specific expertise in health markets. We recommend establishing a formal cooperation protocol between the Agency and health regulators.
assessments.reasoning: Montenegro's pharmaceutical market is characterized by a small number of distributors and wholesalers serving a population of roughly 620,000, creating conditions ripe for market concentration and anti-competitive behavior. The current landscape, where a handful of pharmaceutical distributors dominate supply chains to the Clinical Center of Montenegro and the broader hospital network, has long raised concerns about pricing transparency and potential cartel-like coordination. Strengthening the Competition Protection Agency's investigative powers directly addresses this vulnerability. The ability to impose fines of up to 10% of global revenue is particularly relevant for international pharmaceutical companies and their local subsidiaries operating in Montenegro. This deterrent could discourage practices such as bid-rigging in public procurement for medicines and medical devices, excessive pricing by dominant market players, and market-sharing agreements among distributors that limit patient access to affordable generics. From the perspective of EU accession and Chapter 28 (Consumer and Health Protection), a robust competition framework is a prerequisite. The European Commission has repeatedly noted in its annual progress reports on Montenegro that competition enforcement remains weak. Strengthening this framework supports the broader health acquis alignment, as EU health policy relies heavily on functional competition in pharmaceutical and healthcare markets to keep costs manageable and quality high. The operational and financial independence of the Agency is also welcome. In a small country like Montenegro, where political and business networks are closely intertwined, an independent competition authority is essential to prevent regulatory capture, particularly in health procurement where public spending through the RFZO represents a significant portion of the national budget. However, the law's impact on health will remain theoretical unless the Agency develops specific competence in analyzing healthcare and pharmaceutical markets. Competition cases in health are technically complex, involving issues like parallel trade in medicines, reference pricing systems, and the balance between intellectual property protection and generic market entry. Without dedicated health-market expertise within the Agency, enforcement in this sector may lag behind other industries. Additionally, the Ministry notes that competition law reform alone will not resolve structural problems in Montenegro's health financing system. The RFZO's limited budget, combined with a small risk pool, means that even in a perfectly competitive market, Montenegro will face challenges in negotiating favorable drug prices compared to larger EU member states. Joint procurement mechanisms, such as those being explored through regional Western Balkan health cooperation initiatives, remain essential complements to domestic competition enforcement.
key_concerns: The Competition Protection Agency may lack sector-specific expertise in pharmaceutical and healthcare market dynamics, limiting effective enforcement in health-related cases.
Small market size means even robust competition enforcement cannot fully resolve structural pricing disadvantages Montenegro faces in pharmaceutical procurement.
The law does not explicitly address healthcare-specific anti-competitive practices such as pay-for-delay agreements between originator and generic drug manufacturers.
Risk that enforcement focuses on more straightforward sectors while complex health market cases are deprioritized due to technical difficulty.
No clear mechanism for coordination between the Competition Protection Agency and health sector regulators such as the Agency for Medicines and Medical Devices (CALIMS) or the RFZO.
recommendations: Establish a formal memorandum of understanding between the Competition Protection Agency and CALIMS to facilitate information sharing and joint investigations in pharmaceutical markets.
Advocate for the inclusion of at least one health economics or pharmaceutical market specialist on the Agency's staff or advisory board.
Request that the Ministry of Economic Development include healthcare procurement and pharmaceutical distribution as priority sectors in the Agency's initial enforcement strategy.

Use this legislative moment to push for complementary amendments to the Law on Medicines that would strengthen generic market entry provisions and reduce barriers to competition in the pharmaceutical supply chain.
Engage with regional Western Balkan joint procurement initiatives to complement domestic competition enforcement with collective bargaining power for drug pricing.
Ensure that the RFZO's public procurement processes for medicines and medical devices are reviewed for competition compliance under the new framework.

counter_proposal.title: Health-Sensitive Competition Enforcement Protocol
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Health would supplement this law by proposing a binding inter-institutional cooperation protocol that embeds health sector priorities into competition enforcement. Rather than relying on the general-purpose Agency to independently identify health market issues, we would create a structured referral and advisory mechanism ensuring pharmaceutical pricing, hospital procurement, and private healthcare market conduct receive dedicated attention.
key_changes: Create a Health Markets Advisory Panel within the Competition Protection Agency, composed of representatives from the Ministry of Health, CALIMS, and the RFZO, to flag priority cases and provide technical guidance.
Mandate annual competition assessments of the pharmaceutical distribution and hospital procurement sectors, with findings reported to the Government and Parliament.
Amend the Law on Medicines in parallel to reduce administrative barriers to generic drug market entry, reinforcing competition from the supply side.

Introduce a formal complaint mechanism allowing healthcare institutions and patient organizations to report suspected anti-competitive practices directly to the Agency with expedited review timelines.
expected_benefits: More effective competition enforcement in health markets, leading to lower medicine prices and better value for RFZO spending.
Earlier detection of anti-competitive practices in pharmaceutical procurement, protecting the limited health budget.
Faster generic drug market entry, improving patient access to affordable medicines.
Stronger institutional coordination that aligns with EU expectations for cross-cutting regulatory cooperation under the accession process.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The cooperation protocol requires no new legislation beyond a government decision or inter-ministerial agreement. The Health Markets Advisory Panel can be established through administrative reorganization within existing budgets. Parallel amendments to the Law on Medicines would require a standard legislative procedure but face minimal political resistance given strong public support for lower drug prices.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Protokol o sprovođenju konkurencije s osvrtom na zdravlje
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo zdravlja bi dopunilo ovaj zakon predlaganjem obavezujućeg međuinstitucionalnog protokola o saradnji koji ugrađuje prioritete zdravstvenog sektora u sprovođenje konkurencije. Umjesto oslanjanja na Agenciju opšte namjene da samostalno identifikuje probleme na zdravstvenom tržištu, stvorili bismo strukturirani mehanizam upućivanja i savjetovanja koji osigurava da cijene lijekova, nabavka u bolnicama i ponašanje na tržištu privatnog zdravstva dobiju posvećenu pažnju.
key_changes_mne: Osnivanje Savjetodavnog panela za zdravstvena tržišta u okviru Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije, sastavljen od predstavnika Ministarstva zdravlja, KALIMS-a i RFZO-a, radi označavanja prioritetnih slučajeva i pružanja stručnih smjernica.
Obavezno sprovođenje godišnjih procjena konkurencije u sektorima distribucije lijekova i bolničke nabavke, s nalazima koji se dostavljaju Vladi i Skupštini.
Paralelno izmjenjivanje Zakona o lijekovima u cilju smanjenja administrativnih prepreka za ulazak generičkih lijekova na tržište, čime se jača konkurencija s ponudbene strane.

Uvođenje formalnog mehanizma za pritužbe koji zdravstvenim ustanovama i organizacijama pacijenata omogućava da Agenciji direktno prijavljuju sumnjive antikonkurentske prakse, uz ubrzane rokove za razmatranje.
expected_benefits_mne: Efikasnije sprovođenje konkurencije na zdravstvenim tržištima, što vodi ka nižim cijenama lijekova i boljoj vrijednosti za novac koji troši RFZO.
Ranije otkrivanje antikonkurentskih praksi u farmaceutskoj nabavci, čime se štiti ograničeni zdravstveni budžet.
Brži ulazak generičkih lijekova na tržište, čime se poboljšava pristup pacijenata pristupačnim lijekovima.
Jača institucionalna koordinacija usklađena s očekivanjima EU-a u pogledu međusektorske regulatorne saradnje u okviru procesa pristupanja.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Protokol o saradnji ne zahtijeva novo zakonodavstvo osim vladine odluke ili međuministarskog sporazuma. Savjetodavni panel za zdravstvena tržišta može se uspostaviti administrativnom reorganizacijom u okviru postojećih budžeta. Paralelne izmjene Zakona o lijekovima zahtijevale bi standardnu zakonodavnu proceduru, ali se suočavaju s minimalnim političkim otporom, s obzirom na snažnu javnu podršku nižim cijenama lijekova.

assessments.summary_mne: Jačanje Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije Crne Gore i usklađivanje sa standardima EU u oblasti konkurencije predstavlja pozitivan pomak za zdravstveni sektor, posebno u pogledu regulacije farmaceutskog tržišta, određivanja cijena zdravstvenih usluga i sprečavanja antikonkurentskih praksi koje povećavaju troškove za RFZO i pacijente. Iako se ne radi o zakonu specifičnom za zdravstveni sektor, njegovi indirektni efekti na cijene lijekova, nabavku medicinskih sredstava i nadzor privatnog zdravstvenog tržišta su značajni i dobrodošli.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ova reforma zakona o konkurenciji je u cjelini pozitivna za zdravstvene ishode u Crnoj Gori, prije svega kroz potencijal da se suzbije antikonkurentsko ponašanje u distribuciji farmaceutskih proizvoda i zdravstvenoj nabavci. Glavni interes Ministarstva zdravlja jeste osiguranje da Agencija za zaštitu konkurencije razvije sektorsku stručnost na zdravstvenim tržištima. Preporučujemo uspostavljanje formalnog protokola o saradnji između Agencije i zdravstvenih regulatora.
key_concerns_mne: Agencija za zaštitu konkurencije može nedostajati sektorska stručnost u oblasti dinamike farmaceutskog i zdravstvenog tržišta, što ograničava efikasno sprovođenje propisa u predmetima vezanim za zdravstvo.
Mala veličina tržišta znači da ni snažno sprovođenje konkurencije ne može u potpunosti riješiti strukturne cjenovne nedostatke s kojima se Crna Gora suočava u nabavci farmaceutskih proizvoda.
Zakon eksplicitno ne reguliše antikonkurentske prakse specifične za zdravstvo, kao što su sporazumi o odlaganju plaćanja između proizvođača originalnih i generičkih lijekova.
Postoji rizik da se sprovođenje propisa fokusira na jednostavnije sektore, dok se složeni predmeti na zdravstvenom tržištu stavljaju u drugi plan zbog tehničke složenosti.
Ne postoji jasan mehanizam za koordinaciju između Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i regulatora u zdravstvenom sektoru, kao što su Agencija za lijekove i medicinska sredstva (CALIMS) ili RFZO.
recommendations_mne: Uspostaviti formalni memorandum o razumijevanju između Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i CALIMS-a radi olakšavanja razmjene informacija i zajedničkih istraga na farmaceutskim tržištima.
Zagovarati uključivanje najmanje jednog stručnjaka za zdravstvenu ekonomiju ili farmaceutsko tržište u osoblje ili savjetodavni odbor Agencije.
Zatražiti od Ministarstva ekonomskog razvoja da nabavku u zdravstvu i distribuciju farmaceutskih proizvoda uvrsti kao prioritetne sektore u početnoj strategiji sprovođenja propisa Agencije.

Iskoristiti ovaj zakonodavni trenutak za podsticanje komplementarnih izmjena Zakona o lijekovima koje bi ojačale odredbe o ulasku generika na tržište i smanjile prepreke konkurenciji u lancu snabdijevanja farmaceutskim proizvodima.
Angažovati se u regionalnim inicijativama zajedničke nabavke Zapadnog Balkana kako bi se domaće sprovođenje konkurencije dopunilo kolektivnom pregovaračkom moći u pogledu cijena lijekova.
Osigurati da procesi javne nabavke RFZO-a za lijekove i medicinska sredstva budu pregledani radi usklađenosti s konkurencijom u okviru novog zakonskog okvira.

assessments.summary: The new Competition Protection Law is primarily an economic regulation matter outside the Ministry of Interior's core mandate, but it carries meaningful indirect benefits for our domain. Strengthened investigative powers for the Competition Protection Agency and enhanced enforcement against market manipulation can complement Interior's efforts to combat economic crime, money laundering, and organized crime networks that often exploit weak regulatory environments. The law's alignment with EU standards also supports Montenegro's Chapter 24 (Justice, Freedom, and Security) accession process by demonstrating institutional capacity for independent enforcement.
assessments.executive_summary: The Ministry of Interior views this law positively as an indirect but valuable complement to anti-organized crime efforts. Our primary concern is ensuring the Competition Protection Agency's new investigative powers are coordinated with existing law enforcement mechanisms. We recommend establishing formal inter-agency cooperation protocols between the Agency and the Police Directorate.
assessments.reasoning:
From the Interior Ministry's perspective, this decision is relevant on several axes, though none fall within our primary competence. First, competition law enforcement intersects with economic crime. Organized crime groups in Montenegro and the Western Balkans frequently engage in bid-rigging, cartel activity, and market manipulation as methods of laundering proceeds or consolidating economic influence. A stronger Competition Protection Agency with real investigative teeth can serve as an early warning system for detecting patterns that may indicate organized criminal involvement in legitimate markets. The provision allowing fines up to 10% of global revenue is a serious deterrent that aligns with EU Directive 2019/1 (the ECN+ Directive) and signals to both domestic and international actors that Montenegro is closing regulatory gaps.

Second, the operational and financial independence of the Agency is a positive development for Montenegro's broader institutional landscape. The Ministry of Interior has long advocated for independent, depoliticized enforcement bodies as part of public administration reform. A credible, independent Competition Protection Agency strengthens the rule-of-law ecosystem that Interior depends on for effective policing and prosecution.

Third, from an EU accession standpoint, this law supports the broader negotiation framework. While it most directly addresses Chapter 8 (Competition Policy), the institutional credibility it builds indirectly supports Chapter 23 and Chapter 24 benchmarks, where Montenegro must demonstrate that enforcement bodies operate independently and effectively.

However, the law as described does not appear to address the critical question of inter-agency cooperation. The Competition Protection Agency will gain investigative powers that may overlap with or complement those of the Police Directorate (Uprava policije), the Special State Prosecutor's Office, and the Agency for Prevention of Corruption. Without formal memoranda of understanding or legal provisions for information sharing, there is a risk of parallel investigations, evidence contamination, or missed opportunities to escalate competition violations into criminal proceedings when organized crime is involved. This is particularly relevant in Montenegro's small market where cartels and bid-rigging often involve politically exposed persons or individuals with links to organized crime structures.

Additionally, the Ministry notes that expanded investigative powers for any state body must be accompanied by adequate safeguards against abuse, proper training for investigators, and oversight mechanisms. The Interior Ministry's own experience with building investigative capacity under EU guidance suggests that legal authority without corresponding human resource investment yields limited results.
key_concerns: No apparent provisions for formal cooperation between the Competition Protection Agency and law enforcement bodies such as the Police Directorate or the Special State Prosecutor's Office
Risk of parallel or conflicting investigations where competition violations overlap with criminal economic activity or organized crime
Expanded investigative powers require trained personnel and adequate resources, which the Agency may lack without significant capacity investment
Absence of clear protocols for escalating competition cases to criminal proceedings when evidence of organized crime or corruption emerges
Potential for the Agency's new powers to be misused without robust internal oversight and judicial review mechanisms
recommendations: Establish a formal Memorandum of Understanding between the Competition Protection Agency and the Police Directorate for information sharing on cases with potential criminal dimensions
Include provisions in the law requiring the Agency to refer cases to the Special State Prosecutor's Office when investigations reveal evidence of organized crime, corruption, or money laundering
Ensure the law mandates judicial authorization for any investigative measures that intrude on privacy or business confidentiality, consistent with European Convention on Human Rights standards
Coordinate with the Ministry of Interior's ongoing Schengen and EU accession preparations to present a unified institutional reform narrative in Chapter 23 and 24 benchmarking reports
Request that the Ministry of Economic Development consult with Interior on provisions related to investigative procedures to ensure compatibility with the Criminal Procedure Code

counter_proposal.title: Integrated Economic Crime Enforcement Framework
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than strengthening the Competition Protection Agency in isolation, the Ministry of Interior would advocate for embedding this reform within a broader inter-agency economic crime enforcement framework. This would formally link competition enforcement with the Police Directorate's financial crime units, the Special State Prosecutor's Office, the Agency for Prevention of Corruption, and the Administration for Prevention of Money Laundering. A joint operational protocol would ensure that intelligence flows between agencies, competition cases with criminal indicators are escalated promptly, and Montenegro presents a cohesive enforcement architecture to EU evaluators.
key_changes: Add a legal provision requiring mandatory referral to law enforcement when the Competition Protection Agency encounters evidence of criminal conduct during investigations
Establish a standing inter-agency coordination body for economic crime that includes the Competition Protection Agency alongside the Police Directorate and prosecutors
Include data-sharing provisions compatible with existing law enforcement databases and the Schengen Information System preparatory framework
Require joint training programs between Competition Protection Agency investigators and Police Directorate financial crime units
expected_benefits: Faster detection and prosecution of organized crime groups operating through market manipulation and bid-rigging
Stronger evidence packages for criminal cases that originate from competition investigations
Enhanced credibility with EU evaluators who assess Montenegro's cross-institutional cooperation under Chapters 23 and 24
Prevention of intelligence silos that currently allow criminal actors to exploit gaps between regulatory and law enforcement bodies
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The legal and institutional mechanisms for inter-agency cooperation already exist in Montenegrin law (Law on Internal Affairs, Law on Prevention of Money Laundering). What is required is political will to extend these frameworks to include the Competition Protection Agency and to allocate resources for joint training. This could be achieved through amendments during the parliamentary procedure or through a subsequent Government Conclusion mandating inter-agency protocols.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Integrisani okvir za borbu protiv ekonomskog kriminala
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto jačanja Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije kao izolovane mjere, Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova bi se zalagalo za ugrađivanje ove reforme u širi međuagencijski okvir za suzbijanje ekonomskog kriminala. Time bi se formalno povezalo provođenje propisa o zaštiti konkurencije s jedinicama za finansijski kriminal Uprave policije, Specijalnim državnim tužilaštvom, Agencijom za sprečavanje korupcije i Upravom za sprečavanje pranja novca. Zajednički operativni protokol osigurao bi protok obavještajnih podataka između agencija, pravovremenu eskalaciju predmeta u oblasti konkurencije koji sadrže krivične elemente, te bi Crna Gora dobila kohezivnu arhitekturu provođenja propisa pred ocjenjivačima EU.
key_changes_mne: Uvesti zakonsku odredbu kojom se propisuje obavezno upućivanje predmeta organima gonjenja kada Agencija za zaštitu konkurencije u toku istrage naiđe na dokaze o krivičnom djelu
Uspostaviti stalno međuagencijsko tijelo za koordinaciju u oblasti ekonomskog kriminala koje uključuje Agenciju za zaštitu konkurencije zajedno s Upravom policije i tužilaštvom
Uvesti odredbe o razmjeni podataka koje su kompatibilne s postojećim bazama podataka organa za sprovođenje zakona i pripremnim okvirom Šengenskog informacionog sistema
Obavezati na zajedničke programe obuke između istražitelja Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i jedinica za finansijski kriminal Uprave policije
expected_benefits_mne: Brže otkrivanje i krivično gonjenje organizovanih kriminalnih grupa koje djeluju putem manipulacije tržištem i namještanja tendera
Čvršći dokazni materijal za krivične predmete koji nastaju iz istraga u oblasti zaštite konkurencije
Jači kredibilitet pred ocjenjivačima EU koji procjenjuju međuinstitucionalnu saradnju Crne Gore u okviru Poglavlja 23 i 24
Sprečavanje informacionih silosa koji trenutno omogućavaju kriminalnim akterima da iskorištavaju praznine između regulatornih i tijela za sprovođenje zakona
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno izvodljivo. Pravni i institucionalni mehanizmi za međuagencijsku saradnju već postoje u crnogorskom zakonodavstvu (Zakon o unutrašnjim poslovima, Zakon o sprečavanju pranja novca). Ono što je potrebno jeste politička volja da se ovi okviri prošire tako da obuhvate Agenciju za zaštitu konkurencije i da se obezbijede resursi za zajedničku obuku. To bi se moglo postići izmjenama i dopunama tokom parlamentarne procedure ili naknadnim Zaključkom Vlade kojim se nalažu međuagencijski protokoli.

assessments.summary_mne: Novi Zakon o zaštiti konkurencije primarno je pitanje ekonomske regulative koje se nalazi izvan osnovnog mandata Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova, ali donosi značajne posredne koristi za naš djelokrug. Ojačana istražna ovlašćenja Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i pojačano sankcionisanje manipulacija na tržištu mogu dopuniti napore MUP-a u suzbijanju privrednog kriminala, pranja novca i mreža organizovanog kriminala koje često iskorišćavaju slaba regulatorna okruženja. Usklađenost zakona sa standardima EU takođe podržava crnogorski proces pristupanja u okviru Poglavlja 24 (Pravda, sloboda i bezbjednost), demonstrirajući institucionalne kapacitete za nezavisno sprovođenje propisa.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova pozitivno ocjenjuje ovaj zakon kao posrednu, ali vrijednu dopunu naporima u borbi protiv organizovanog kriminala. Naša primarna preokupacija jeste osiguranje da nova istražna ovlašćenja Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije budu koordinisana sa postojećim mehanizmima sprovođenja zakona. Preporučujemo uspostavljanje formalnih protokola o međuagencijskoj saradnji između Agencije i Uprave policije.
key_concerns_mne: Nema vidljivih odredbi o formalnoj saradnji između Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i tijela za sprovođenje zakona, kao što su Uprava policije ili Specijalno državno tužilaštvo
Rizik od paralelnih ili sukobljenih istraga u slučajevima kada povrede konkurencije prelaze u oblast krivičnih privrednih aktivnosti ili organizovanog kriminala
Proširena istražna ovlašćenja zahtijevaju obučen kadar i odgovarajuće resurse, koje Agencija možda ne posjeduje bez značajnih ulaganja u izgradnju kapaciteta
Odsustvo jasnih protokola za eskalaciju predmeta iz oblasti konkurencije u krivični postupak u slučajevima kada se pojave dokazi o organizovanom kriminalu ili korupciji
Mogućnost zloupotrebe novih ovlašćenja Agencije bez snažnog internog nadzora i mehanizama sudske kontrole
recommendations_mne: Zaključiti formalni Memorandum o razumijevanju između Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i Uprave policije radi razmjene informacija u predmetima sa potencijalnom krivičnom dimenzijom
U zakon uvrstiti odredbe koje obavezuju Agenciju da predmete upućuje Specijalnom državnom tužilaštvu kada istrage otkriju dokaze o organizovanom kriminalu, korupciji ili pranju novca
Obezbijediti da zakon nalaže sudsko odobrenje za sve istražne mjere kojima se zadire u privatnost ili poslovnu povjerljivost, u skladu sa standardima Evropske konvencije o ljudskim pravima

Uskladiti aktivnosti sa tekućim pripremama Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova za Šengen i pristupanje EU, kako bi se u izvještajima o mjerilima za poglavlja 23 i 24 predstavila jedinstvena naracija o institucionalnim reformama
Zatražiti od Ministarstva ekonomskog razvoja da se konsultuje sa MUP-om o odredbama koje se odnose na istražne postupke, radi osiguranja usklađenosti sa Zakonikom o krivičnom postupku

assessments.summary: The strengthening of Montenegro's Competition Protection Agency and alignment with EU competition standards is a positive development for the tourism sector. While not a tourism-specific measure, robust competition enforcement directly addresses several structural problems in Montenegrin tourism, including market concentration among coastal hoteliers, opaque concession arrangements for beach and national park management, and anticompetitive practices in the cruise ship services supply chain. The law's alignment with EU acquis Chapter 8 (Competition Policy) also strengthens Montenegro's EU accession trajectory, which is itself a signal of regulatory credibility to international tourism investors and operators.
assessments.executive_summary: This law is a net positive for tourism, as stronger competition enforcement can tackle market concentration along the coast, improve transparency in beach and park concessions, and advance EU accession. The Ministry of Tourism recommends the Competition Protection Agency develop sector-specific expertise in tourism markets and that concession frameworks be explicitly included in the enforcement scope.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's tourism sector suffers from several competition-related distortions that this law could help address. First, the coastal accommodation market, particularly in Budva, Kotor, and Tivat, is characterized by a small number of large hotel groups and real estate developers that can exert significant pricing power during the peak season (May to October). Stronger merger control and abuse-of-dominance provisions could prevent further consolidation and protect smaller, family-run establishments that contribute to authentic tourism experiences and distribute economic benefits more broadly.

Second, the beach concession system has long been a source of concern. Concessions for public beaches are often awarded through processes that lack transparency, leading to monopolistic pricing of sunbeds and parasols that damages Montenegro's price competitiveness relative to Albania and Greece. An empowered Competition Protection Agency with genuine investigative powers could scrutinize these arrangements and challenge anticompetitive terms.

Third, the cruise ship services market in Kotor Bay is highly concentrated. Port services, excursion operators, and ground transport for cruise passengers are dominated by a small number of firms, which limits service quality and inflates costs. Given that Kotor is a UNESCO World Heritage Site under carrying capacity pressure, competition enforcement could complement the Ministry of Tourism's broader efforts to manage visitor flows by ensuring that the economic benefits of cruise tourism are not captured by a narrow group of operators.

Fourth, the national park concession and service provision model (covering Durmitor, Biogradska Gora, Skadar Lake, Prokletije, and Lovcen) would benefit from competition oversight. Exclusive arrangements for accommodation, food services, and guided tours within parks can suppress quality and innovation. Stronger enforcement could open these markets to more operators, improving the ecotourism product.

From an EU accession perspective, alignment with EU competition standards under Chapter 8 of the acquis communautaire is essential. The European Commission has repeatedly flagged weak competition enforcement as a concern in Montenegro's annual progress reports. A credible competition framework improves Montenegro's standing in accession negotiations and signals to EU-based tourism investors and tour operators that the market operates on fair and predictable rules.

The law's provision for fines of up to 10 percent of global revenue is significant and mirrors EU Regulation 1/2003. This creates a credible deterrent, though enforcement capacity and political independence of the Agency will determine whether fines are actually imposed. Montenegro's track record on independent agency operations is mixed, and the tourism sector is politically connected, so implementation risk remains.

The main limitation of this decision from a tourism perspective is that it is a horizontal, economy-wide measure. It does not contain sector-specific provisions for tourism markets, which have unique characteristics such as extreme seasonality, geographic concentration, and the interplay between public assets (beaches, parks, heritage sites) and private operators. Without sector-specific guidance or a dedicated unit within the Agency, tourism markets may not receive the attention they warrant.
key_concerns: The Competition Protection Agency may lack sector-specific expertise in tourism markets, which have unique characteristics such as seasonality, geographic concentration, and public asset concessions.
Political independence of the Agency remains uncertain given Montenegro's governance track record; tourism-connected business interests could resist enforcement in practice.
Beach and national park concession arrangements may fall in a grey zone between competition law and public procurement law, potentially creating enforcement gaps.
Small and medium tourism enterprises may lack the resources to file complaints or participate in proceedings, limiting the law's practical benefit to those who need it most.

The law does not address the short-term rental platform market (Airbnb, Booking.com), where platform dominance and algorithmic pricing raise distinct competition concerns for the accommodation sector.
recommendations: The Ministry of Tourism should formally request the Competition Protection Agency to conduct a sector inquiry into coastal tourism markets, covering hotel accommodation, beach concessions, and cruise ship port services.
Advocate for the establishment of a tourism and services unit within the Agency, staffed with analysts who understand seasonal market dynamics and tourism-specific competition issues.

Ensure that the concession framework for beaches and national parks is explicitly included within the scope of competition enforcement, closing any gap between competition law and public procurement regulations.
Develop a simplified complaint mechanism for small and medium tourism operators, including seasonal businesses, to report anticompetitive practices without prohibitive legal costs.

Coordinate with the Agency on monitoring dominant digital platforms (Booking.com, Airbnb) and their impact on accommodation market competition, pricing transparency, and housing availability in coastal municipalities.

counter_proposal.title: Tourism-Specific Competition Enforcement Protocol
counter_proposal.summary: While supporting the horizontal competition law reform, the Ministry of Tourism would push for a complementary tourism sector protocol that directs the Competition Protection Agency to prioritize tourism markets, conduct a baseline sector inquiry within 12 months, and establish formal coordination with the Ministry of Tourism on concession-related competition matters.
key_changes: Include a provision requiring the Agency to conduct a sector inquiry into coastal and national park tourism markets within 12 months of the law's entry into force.
Establish a formal memorandum of cooperation between the Competition Protection Agency and the Ministry of Tourism for information sharing on concession awards and market developments.
Create a fast-track complaint channel for seasonal tourism operators that accounts for the compressed May-to-October business cycle.
Add explicit provisions clarifying that public beach and national park service concessions fall within the scope of competition enforcement.
Mandate annual reporting by the Agency on competition conditions in the tourism sector as part of Montenegro's EU accession monitoring.
expected_benefits: More competitive pricing for tourists on beaches and in national parks, improving Montenegro's value proposition against Croatia and Albania.
Greater market entry for small operators and startups in coastal and ecotourism services, diversifying the tourism product.
Improved transparency in concession awards, reducing corruption perceptions that damage Montenegro's tourism brand.
Stronger EU accession case by demonstrating sector-specific application of competition principles in a sector representing roughly 40 percent of GDP.
Better data and market intelligence on tourism competition dynamics, informing future policy and regulation.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The proposed protocol does not require separate legislation and can be implemented through a government decision or memorandum of understanding between the Agency and the Ministry. The sector inquiry can be funded through existing Agency resources, and EU technical assistance under IPA III could support capacity building. Political feasibility depends on willingness to scrutinize concession arrangements, which are politically sensitive but increasingly expected by the European Commission.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Protokol o sprovođenju konkurencije specifičan za turizam
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Uz podršku horizontalnoj reformi zakona o konkurenciji, Ministarstvo turizma zalagalo bi se za komplementarni protokol turističkog sektora koji usmjerava Agenciju za zaštitu konkurencije da prioritizuje turistička tržišta, sprovede osnovno sektorsko ispitivanje u roku od 12 mjeseci i uspostavi formalnu koordinaciju sa Ministarstvom turizma po pitanjima konkurencije vezanim za koncesije.
key_changes_mne: Uključiti odredbu kojom se obavezuje Agencija da sprovede sektorsko ispitivanje obalnih tržišta i tržišta turizma u nacionalnim parkovima u roku od 12 mjeseci od stupanja zakona na snagu.
Uspostaviti formalni memorandum o saradnji između Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i Ministarstva turizma radi razmjene informacija o dodjeli koncesija i tržišnim kretanjima.
Kreirati kanal za brzo rješavanje pritužbi za sezonske turističke operatere, uzimajući u obzir sažeti poslovni ciklus od maja do oktobra.
Dodati izričite odredbe koje pojašnjavaju da koncesije za usluge na javnim plažama i u nacionalnim parkovima spadaju u oblast primjene zaštite konkurencije.
Obavezati Agenciju na godišnje izvještavanje o uslovima konkurencije u turističkom sektoru kao dio monitoringa pristupanja Crne Gore EU.
expected_benefits_mne: Konkurentnije cijene za turiste na plažama i u nacionalnim parkovima, čime se unapređuje vrijednosna ponuda Crne Gore u odnosu na Hrvatsku i Albaniju.
Veći pristup tržištu za male operatere i novoosnovane kompanije u obalnim i ekoturističkim uslugama, čime se diverzifikuje turistička ponuda.
Poboljšana transparentnost u dodjeli koncesija, čime se smanjuje percepcija korupcije koja šteti turističkom brendu Crne Gore.
Jači argument za pristupanje EU demonstriranjem sektorski specifične primjene principa konkurencije u sektoru koji čini otprilike 40 posto BDP-a.
Bolji podaci i tržišna inteligencija o dinamici konkurencije u turizmu, što informiše buduću politiku i regulativu.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Predloženi protokol ne zahtijeva posebno zakonodavstvo i može se implementirati putem vladine odluke ili memoranduma o razumijevanju između Agencije i Ministarstva. Sektorsko ispitivanje može se finansirati iz postojećih resursa Agencije, a tehnička pomoć EU u okviru IPA III mogla bi podržati izgradnju kapaciteta. Politička izvodljivost zavisi od spremnosti da se preispitaju koncesionalni aranžmani, koji su politički osjetljivi, ali ih Evropska komisija sve češće očekuje.

assessments.summary_mne: Jačanje Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije Crne Gore i usklađivanje sa standardima EU u oblasti konkurencije pozitivan je razvoj za turistički sektor. Iako nije mjera specifična za turizam, snažna primjena pravila konkurencije direktno se bavi nekoliko strukturnih problema crnogorskog turizma, uključujući koncentraciju tržišta među hoteljerima na primorju, netransparentne koncesijske aranžmane za upravljanje plažama i nacionalnim parkovima, te antikonkurentske prakse u lancu snabdijevanja uslugama kruzera. Usklađivanje zakona sa poglavljem 8 acquis-a EU (Politika konkurencije) takođe jača crnogorski put ka pristupanju EU, što samo po sebi predstavlja signal regulatorne vjerodostojnosti međunarodnim investitorima i operaterima u turizmu.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovaj zakon ima neto pozitivan učinak na turizam, budući da snažnije sprovođenje pravila konkurencije može suzbiti koncentraciju tržišta duž primorja, poboljšati transparentnost u koncesijama za plaže i parkove i ubrzati pristupanje EU. Ministarstvo turizma preporučuje da Agencija za zaštitu konkurencije razvije sektorsku stručnost u oblasti turističkih tržišta i da koncesijski okviri budu izričito uključeni u djelokrug primjene.
key_concerns_mne: Agenciji za zaštitu konkurencije može nedostajati sektorska stručnost u oblasti turističkih tržišta, koja imaju jedinstvene karakteristike kao što su sezonalnost, geografska koncentracija i koncesije na javnu imovinu.

Politička nezavisnost Agencije ostaje neizvjesna s obzirom na dosadašnji učinak Crne Gore u oblasti upravljanja; poslovni interesi povezani s turizmom mogli bi u praksi pružati otpor sprovođenju mjera.
Koncesijski aranžmani za plaže i nacionalne parkove mogu se naći u sivoj zoni između zakona o konkurenciji i zakona o javnim nabavkama, što potencijalno stvara praznine u primjeni.
Mala i srednja turistička preduzeća mogu nemati dovoljno resursa za podnošenje pritužbi ili učešće u postupcima, što ograničava praktičnu korist zakona za one kojima je najpotrebnija.

Zakon ne reguliše tržište platformi za kratkoročni najam (Airbnb, Booking.com), gdje dominacija platformi i algoritamsko određivanje cijena postavljaju posebna pitanja konkurencije u sektoru smještaja.
recommendations_mne: Ministarstvo turizma treba zvanično da zatraži od Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije sprovođenje sektorske istrage turističkih tržišta na primorju, koja bi obuhvatila hotelski smještaj, koncesije na plaže i lučke usluge za kruzere.
Zalagati se za osnivanje jedinice za turizam i usluge unutar Agencije, koja bi bila popunjena analitičarima koji razumiju sezonsku dinamiku tržišta i pitanja konkurencije specifična za turizam.

Osigurati da koncesijski okvir za plaže i nacionalne parkove bude izričito uključen u djelokrug primjene pravila konkurencije, čime bi se zatvorila svaka praznina između zakona o konkurenciji i propisa o javnim nabavkama.

Razviti pojednostavljen mehanizam za podnošenje pritužbi za male i srednje turističke operatere, uključujući sezonska preduzeća, radi prijavljivanja antikonkurentskih praksi bez nedostupnih pravnih troškova.

Koordinisati se sa Agencijom u pogledu praćenja dominantnih digitalnih platformi (Booking.com, Airbnb) i njihovog uticaja na konkurenciju na tržištu smještaja, transparentnost cijena i dostupnost stanovanja u primorskim opštinama.

assessments.summary: The strengthening of competition protection in Montenegro is a structurally positive development for workers and social welfare, even though the law does not directly address labour policy. Effective competition enforcement combats market concentration, which tends to suppress wages, reduce employment opportunities, and weaken workers' bargaining power. Alignment with EU standards under Chapter 8 (Competition Policy) also indirectly supports progress on Chapter 19 (Social Policy and Employment) by demonstrating institutional capacity and regulatory credibility. However, the draft law appears to lack any explicit provisions linking competition enforcement to labour market outcomes, social impact assessments, or worker protections during corporate restructurings triggered by antitrust actions.
assessments.executive_summary: This law is a welcome step toward EU-aligned market governance that should indirectly benefit workers through fairer competition, better wages, and more dynamic job creation. The Ministry's primary concern is the absence of labour and social safeguards in merger reviews and antitrust enforcement actions. We recommend integrating mandatory social impact assessments and worker consultation mechanisms into the competition framework.
assessments.reasoning:
Competition policy and labour policy are more closely linked than is commonly acknowledged. International evidence, including OECD and ILO research, demonstrates that labour market monopsony (where few employers dominate hiring in a region or sector) depresses wages, worsens working conditions, and increases informal employment. Montenegro's small economy, with significant market concentration in sectors such as tourism, retail, energy, and construction, makes this connection particularly relevant. When a handful of employers dominate a sector, workers lose bargaining leverage regardless of what labour law formally guarantees.

The proposed law's alignment with the EU acquis under Chapter 8 is important for Montenegro's accession process. A credible, independent Competition Protection Agency can address abusive practices by dominant employers, including wage-fixing agreements, no-poach clauses, and exploitative supply chain practices that ultimately harm workers. The increase in fines to up to 10 percent of global revenue is a meaningful deterrent that brings Montenegro closer to EU enforcement standards.

However, the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare notes several gaps. First, merger control decisions in the EU increasingly consider employment effects, yet the Montenegrin draft appears to treat competition purely through a consumer welfare lens. When the Agency reviews mergers or acquisitions, particularly in labour-intensive sectors like tourism or food processing, the impact on local employment, collective agreements, and social protection contributions should be assessed. Montenegro has already experienced cases where consolidation in retail and hospitality led to workforce reductions, deterioration of working conditions, and weakening of union presence.

Second, when the Agency imposes fines or orders structural remedies such as divestitures, there is no apparent mechanism to protect workers affected by resulting corporate restructurings. The Zakon o radu provides general protections for redundancy, but antitrust-driven restructurings can be sudden and large-scale, requiring coordination between the Competition Agency, the Employment Bureau (Zavod za zaposljavnje), and Centres for Social Work.

Third, the law's focus on operational and financial independence for the Agency is commendable, but there is no indication that the Social Council (Socijalni savjet) or trade union representatives were consulted during the drafting process. Given that competition decisions directly affect employment structures, this represents a missed opportunity for social dialogue, which is a core requirement under both ILO conventions and Chapter 19 of the EU acquis.

Finally, from a demographic perspective, Montenegro faces severe emigration of working-age population and rising youth unemployment. Competition policy that promotes market dynamism and lowers barriers to entry for small and medium enterprises can help create new employment opportunities. But this potential will only be realized if competition enforcement is coordinated with active labour market policies, vocational training programs, and social enterprise development, none of which appear to be referenced in the draft.
key_concerns: No mandatory social or employment impact assessment in merger control and antitrust enforcement proceedings
Absence of worker protection mechanisms when competition enforcement actions trigger corporate restructuring or workforce reductions
No evidence of consultation with the Social Council, trade unions, or employers' associations during the drafting process, contrary to social dialogue principles
The law appears to adopt a purely consumer welfare standard without considering labour market effects such as monopsony power and wage suppression
No coordination mechanism between the Competition Protection Agency and labour market institutions such as the Employment Bureau and Centres for Social Work
Risk that large fines on domestically significant employers could lead to layoffs or wage arrears without accompanying social safeguards
recommendations: Introduce a mandatory employment and social impact assessment as part of the merger review process, particularly for transactions affecting sectors with high labour concentration

Establish a formal consultation protocol between the Competition Protection Agency and the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare for enforcement actions likely to affect employment levels or working conditions
Ensure the Social Council is consulted on the draft law before parliamentary adoption, in line with Montenegro's obligations under ILO Convention No. 144 on tripartite consultation
Include anti-monopsony provisions that explicitly address employer collusion on wages, no-poach agreements, and other labour market restraints as competition violations
Create a worker transition fund or rapid-response mechanism, coordinated with the Employment Bureau, to support workers displaced by antitrust-driven restructurings
Link competition policy objectives with the National Employment Strategy to ensure that market liberalisation translates into quality job creation rather than precarious employment

counter_proposal.title: Competition Law with Integrated Labour Market Safeguards
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare supports the core objectives of the draft law but would amend it to include mandatory employment impact assessments in merger reviews, explicit prohibition of employer wage-fixing and no-poach agreements as competition violations, a formal inter-institutional coordination mechanism with labour market bodies, and a requirement for tripartite consultation on major enforcement actions affecting employment. This approach mirrors emerging best practices in the EU, where DG Competition and DG Employment increasingly coordinate, and in the United States, where the DOJ and FTC have begun prosecuting labour market restraints as antitrust violations.
key_changes: Add an article requiring employment and social impact assessment for merger notifications above a defined workforce threshold
Explicitly classify employer wage-fixing agreements and no-poach clauses as hardcore competition restrictions subject to the highest fines
Mandate that the Competition Protection Agency notify and consult the Ministry of Labour when enforcement actions may result in significant workforce displacement
Require tripartite consultation through the Social Council during the law's parliamentary review phase
Establish a joint working group between the Competition Agency, Employment Bureau, and Centres for Social Work for post-enforcement worker support
expected_benefits: Workers in concentrated sectors gain protection against both product market and labour market abuses of dominance
Merger reviews account for employment effects, preventing approval of transactions that create local labour market monopsonies
Social dialogue obligations under EU Chapter 19 and ILO conventions are respected in competition policy design
Displaced workers receive coordinated institutional support, reducing social protection costs and emigration pressure
Montenegro demonstrates a holistic approach to EU acquis alignment by linking Chapter 8 and Chapter 19 reforms
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The proposed amendments require no additional budgetary allocation and can be integrated into the existing draft before parliamentary submission. Employment impact assessments in merger reviews follow established EU member state practices. The main challenge is inter-institutional coordination, which can be addressed through a memorandum of understanding between the Competition Agency and the Ministry of Labour, achievable within the current legislative cycle.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Zakon o zaštiti konkurencije s integrисаnim zaštitnim mjerama na tržištu rada
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo rada i socijalnog staranja podržava ključne ciljeve nacrta zakona, ali predlaže njegovo izmjenu kako bi se uključili: obavezne procjene uticaja na zapošljavanje u postupcima ispitivanja spajanja privrednih subjekata, izričita zabrana sporazuma poslodavaca o fiksiranju zarada i klauzula o zabrani zapošljavanja kao povreda konkurencije, formalni mehanizam međuinstitucionalne koordinacije s tijelima nadležnim za tržište rada, te obaveza tripartitnih konsultacija o značajnim mjerama izvršavanja koje utiču na zaposlenost. Ovaj pristup odražava sve prisutnije dobre prakse u EU, gdje DG za konkurenciju i DG za zapošljavanje u sve većoj mjeri koordiniraju svoj rad, kao i u Sjedinjenim Američkim Državama, gdje su DOJ i FTC počeli procesuirati ograničenja na tržištu rada kao povrede antitrustovskog zakonodavstva.
key_changes_mne: Dodati član kojim se uvodi obaveza procjene uticaja na zapošljavanje i socijalnih efekata za prijave spajanja koje prelaze utvrđeni prag broja zaposlenih
Izričito klasifikovati sporazume poslodavaca o fiksiranju zarada i klauzule o zabrani zapošljavanja kao teška ograničenja konkurencije koja podliježu najvišim novčanim kaznama
Obavezati Agenciju za zaštitu konkurencije da obavijesti Ministarstvo rada i s njim se konsultuje kada mjere izvršavanja mogu dovesti do značajnijeg smanjenja broja zaposlenih
Obezbijediti tripartitne konsultacije putem Socijalnog savjeta u toku faze parlamentarne rasprave o zakonu
Uspostaviti zajednički radni tim između Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije, Zavoda za zapošljavanje i Centara za socijalni rad radi pružanja podrške radnicima nakon sprovedenih mjera izvršavanja
expected_benefits_mne: Radnici u koncentrisanim sektorima dobijaju zaštitu kako od zloupotreba dominantnog položaja na tržištu proizvoda, tako i na tržištu rada
Ispitivanje spajanja uzima u obzir efekte na zaposlenost, čime se sprječava odobravanje transakcija koje stvaraju monopsonske pozicije na lokalnim tržištima rada
Obaveze socijalnog dijaloga u skladu s Poglavljem 19 EU i konvencijama MOR-a poštuju se pri oblikovanju politike konkurencije
Raseljeni radnici dobijaju koordinisanu institucionalnu podršku, čime se smanjuju troškovi socijalne zaštite i pritisak iseljavanja
Crna Gora demonstrira sveobuhvatan pristup usklađivanju s pravnom tekovinom EU povezivanjem reformi u okviru Poglavlja 8 i Poglavlja 19
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Predložene izmjene ne zahtijevaju dodatna budžetska sredstva i mogu se uključiti u postojeći nacrt prije upućivanja u parlamentarnu proceduru. Procjene uticaja na zapošljavanje u postupcima ispitivanja spajanja slijede utvrđene prakse država članica EU. Glavni izazov predstavlja međuinstitucionalna koordinacija, koja se može riješiti putem memoranduma o razumijevanju između Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i Ministarstva rada, što je ostvarivo u okviru tekućeg zakonodavnog ciklusa.

assessments.summary_mne: Jačanje zaštite konkurencije u Crnoj Gori predstavlja strukturno pozitivan razvoj za radnike i socijalno blagostanje, iako zakon ne uređuje direktno politiku rada. Djelotvorna primjena propisa o konkurenciji suzbija koncentraciju tržišta, koja teži da potiskuje zarade, smanjuje mogućnosti zapošljavanja i slabi pregovaračku moć radnika. Usklađivanje sa standardima EU u okviru Poglavlja 8 (Politika konkurencije) indirektno podržava i napredak u Poglavlju 19 (Socijalna politika i zapošljavanje), demonstrirajući institucionalnu sposobnost i regulatorni kredibilitet. Međutim, čini se da nacrt zakona ne sadrži nikakve eksplicitne odredbe koje bi povezale primjenu propisa o konkurenciji s ishodima na tržištu rada, procjenama socijalnog uticaja ili zaštitom radnika tokom korporativnog restrukturiranja pokrenutog antimonopolskim mjerama.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovaj zakon predstavlja dobrodošao korak ka upravljanju tržištem usklađenom s EU, koji bi trebalo indirektno da koristi radnicima kroz pravičniju konkurenciju, bolje zarade i dinamičnije otvaranje radnih mjesta. Primarna zabrinutost Ministarstva odnosi se na odsustvo radnih i socijalnih zaštitnih mjera u postupcima preispitivanja spajanja i antimonopolskog izvršenja. Preporučujemo integrisanje obaveznih procjena socijalnog uticaja i mehanizama konsultacija s radnicima u okvir zaštite konkurencije.
key_concerns_mne: Ne postoji obavezna socijalna procjena niti procjena uticaja na zapošljavanje u postupcima kontrole spajanja i antimonopolskog izvršenja
Odsustvo mehanizama zaštite radnika kada mjere primjene propisa o konkurenciji pokrenu korporativno restrukturiranje ili smanjenje broja zaposlenih
